Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-Resolution Underway Air-Sea Observations in Drake Passage for Climate Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Drake Passage is the body of water between South America and the Western Antarctic Peninsula, thus connecting the Southern Atlantic and Southern Pacific Oceans through the unimpeded flow of the immense Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC).

Using the relatively frequent ferry crossings of the Drake Passage by the RV/AS LMGould, the USAP supply ship, this proposal will continue the of collection of upper ocean XBT temperature and XTCD salinity data in this natural chokepoint for the ACC. This will yield additional hydrographic observations on seasonal to interannual timescales, and on spatial scales ranging from the current core to mesoscale eddies. These high-resolution, multi-repeat transects (up to 6 ~7 crossings per year) are quality controlled, archived and made available to the broader community in order to facilitate study of the modes of variability of the dominant oceanic current on the planet (the ACC). The Drake Passage XBT/XCTD transect time series now extends back to 1996, and continues to add to a number of quantitative estimates of the long term trends in Southern Ocean fronts, surface water mass properties, their response to atmospheric forcing on climate relevant time scales. This proposal also seeks renewal of a near decadal time series effort measuring the underway surface partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) in regular transects across the Drake Passage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Annual-mean CO2 uptake by the Southern Ocean and carbon-climate feedbacks in the region have been difficult to diagnose because of sparse observations and because the seasonal exchange of CO2 is driven by strong opposing thermal and biological forces. Because air-sea O2 exchanges are positively correlated for thermal and biological influences, and not affected by buffering chemistry, seasonal air-sea O2 fluxes are considerably larger than their CO2 counterparts. Consequently, atmospheric O2 measurements provide a unique means of investigating the biogeochemical processes driving Southern Ocean CO2 exchange.

This has been a collaborative research project between the University of Colorado at Boulder, the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), and Scripps Institution of Oceanography. The major outcomes of the NCAR portion of the project were the collection of high precision and well calibrated measurements of atmospheric O2 and CO2 from the ARSV L.M. Gould operating in Drake Passage and along the Antarctic Peninsula, and analyses to gain knowledge regarding Southern Ocean biogeochemical cycling. These measurements also supported the O2/N2 Ratio and CO2 Airborne Southern Ocean (ORCAS) Study, giving both spatial and temporal context to the intensive airborne campaign. We have also collaborated with co-PIs conducting underway measurements on the Gould in data analysis and the writing of collaborative papers.

Our instruments on the Gould ran very well for this award period, collecting continuous data on 26 cruises. We share our data freely in near real-time at the website http://www.eol.ucar.edu/~stephens/GO2.

We completed an analysis of the Gould atmospheric O2 timeseries with the specific objectives of characterizing the annual means and seasonal cycles of CO2 and O2 at a range of latitudes between Punta Arenas and Palmer Station and their comparison to a suite of coupled ocean-atmosphere model predictions. We have also analyzed the observed latitudinal gradients in CO2 and O2 in different seasons, and compared these to measurements from the ORCAS project and longer term Scripps records from Palmer Station (PSA) and the South Pole (SPO).

The latitudinal gradient in the seasonal amplitude for O2 as measured on the Gould peaks between 62 and 64 S in Drake Passage. This seasonal amplitude can provide estimates of zonal scale seasonal marine productivity and its latitudinal distribution indicates where air-sea fluxes are greatest. The latitudinal gradients observed by the ship from 53-65 S for CO2 decrease to the south in summer and are relatively flat in winter, consistent with strong summertime CO2 uptake and a balance of influences between CO2 release and transport of northern CO2 signals in winter. For O2, the latitudinal gradients increase strongly to the south in summer and decrease to the south in winter, consistent with Southern Ocean biological and thermal forcing. The ratio of the CO2 and O2 latitudinal gradients in summer, combined with estimates of O2 exchange, reveal the dominance of biological forcing on Southern Ocean CO2 exchange and suggest that climatological estimates may significantly underestimate summertime CO2 uptake.

When docked at Palmer Station, the ship O2 measurements are higher in summer and lower in winter than those from the Palmer Station flask record. Because the ship docks to the west of the station, with a clean air sector over the ocean, while the flasks are collected to the east of the station, with a clean air sector sampling down-glacier and cross-Peninsula winds, O2 measured by the ship reflects greater sensitivity to air-sea fluxes and reveals that previous modeling efforts may have misrepresented the influences on PSA flasks.

Comparisons between the CO2 measurements made as part of our atmospheric O2 effort and atmospheric CO2 measurements from the underway pCO2 system show minimal offsets, and are supporting evaluation of the potential for exploiting the global network of underway pCO2 systems for atmospheric CO2 data.
